question: Who is this? What is wrong with you people? The first two, I thought he might be on a lunar cycle because they were 28 days apart, but obviously not. This new one is only two weeks. You're calling me a crank? I think this is number three... Where were you? Don't tell me. It's just under seventy, right? The sun is strong but the air is dry and fresh...
answer: Would you please get your hands off my face, Tallulah? What happened to the newspaper?

question: I got it myself... I couldn't wait.
answer: Well! Aren't we the daring one? What's morbid and ghastly enough in the news to make Doctor Helen set foot outside her door? The antenna is gone off her car again. I had no music, all the way to the market. Let me find a garage for it?

question: I've told you
answer: Are you kidding? You buy enough gourmet junk every week... most of which rots... to garage a fleet of stretch limos.

question: I had the dream again. And I got another call. This time he spoke. He said "You and me, you and me."
answer: A little heavy breathing is what most of us yearn for. Forget it.

question: He whispered, but it was him! I know it was him!
answer: He can't phone you unless the warden gets an okay from you. Did you give him an approval?

question: Andy? When a three-year-old says there's a monster under the bed, you don't say 'forget it'. You look under the bad. I'm three years old. Call the prison. Oh God. I'm really crazy.
answer: When was the last time you washed your hair?

question: Monsieur Andy, disapproves of my coiffure?
answer: Monsieur Andy can smell your coiffure. And guess what else? Cellulite. What do you say I blindfold you and take you to the gym. Aerobics with housewives...

question: Andy?
answer: Here we go again.

question: You parked right behind him. The one I noticed earlier. I didn't say anything, I thought he'd leave. Just take a look.
answer: Oh my God! Help! HE'S READING A NEWSPAPER!

question: But earlier, he was staring up here. Please, Andy.
answer: Okay. You win. 'Dirty Harry' coming up. Excuse me, but would you mind explaining why you're watching the lady upstairs?

question: Okay. You win. 'Dirty Harry' coming up. Excuse me, but would you mind explaining why you're watching the lady upstairs?
answer: None of your fucking business.

question: Listen, asshole, I've got a gun...
answer: I hate this...

question: Only kidding!
answer: I'm calling the police!

question: I'm okay. I really kind of enjoyed it.
answer: Is he out? If he's not out, why are they here? What calls? I haven't made any calls.

question: Are you staying long? Shall I shut the door? Make your coffee? Make the beds?
answer: You were the one that talked about moonbikes and called me a crank? Oh God, I am! Make them some coffee. Halloran, is it? Investigator Goetz? I had a crank call myself-- he said... I thought it might be Daryll Lee Cullum. I thought he might be out of prison.

question: You called us, Doctor, if you don't want to look at them here, how about downtown. I'll drive you down...
answer: Now look what you did.

question: What did I do?
answer: You threatened to drive her downtown. She has agoraphobia.

question: Fear of what...
answer: Open space. She hasn't been out of this apartment in three years. I didn't used to think it was real... Oh, God, uniforms, more stress. Let her sleep. It's a self-limiting Hey, no. Leave those here. If you really want her help. I mean if you really do, leave them. Let her see them. I'll see they're safe...

question: Classy madonna. You came in there with this attitude...
answer: Shit...

question: ... it was your feeling after careful evaluation that he was a sexual sadist who satisfied at least four out of ten criteria in the DMS III?
answer: Yes. Without question.

question: Without question? He only scored 40 percent, four out of ten criteria? Couldn't another expert say he flunked the sexual sadist test? What curve are you marking on, Doctor?
answer: The test criteria are only part of what we look at in evaluating subjects.

question: Only part. What else? What did you think of his claim that he tied this girl to the tree and set fire to her because Joan of Arc told him to do it.
answer: He was lying.

question: 'Lying. He was lying.' I asked you what you thought, not what he did.
answer: I thought he was lying.

question: You said, first, he was lying. How do you know that, Doctor?
answer: Because people who are suffering from aural hallucinations hear voices in both ears. Daryll Lee told me that Joan of Arc always appeared beside him on his left side and spoke softly in his left ear. He took pains to hide his actions because he knew they were morally wrong. He was not acting on mad impulse. He was sane and acting out a pattern he carefully followed every time.

question: What pattern was that?
answer: The same as the first time...

question: The first what? Your Honor, she's got this far, I think she should finish. I don't think this jury should be left wondering where the rest of her statement would lead.
answer: The first two murders.

question: What first two murders. We don't know about them here, do we?
answer: He told me he had done two others just like it.

question: When was that?
answer: When he was seventeen.

question: And you believed him when he told you he had done that.
answer: Yes. I believed him.

question: Oh, God. I must have looked horrible.
answer: No, dear. You're at your best with a bag in front of your face.

question: I want to die.
answer: I wouldn't. He'll be back. If you want him. The cute brutal type with handcuffs. Very sexy. You thought he was cute too, didn't you? Admit... admit... What? What'd I do?

question: Reminded me that I used to be attractive. That men used to want me...
answer: You slut! No sexy young cop for you unless you shampoo your hair. When are you going to call them?

question: About what? I can't, Andy.
answer: Then, why don't you just die. I'm going. They'll find your body years later, the old recluse lady, she ate cat food, ten years of the New York Times, unread, piled on top of the unread mail, the TV still on. Make up your mind. Live or die. I'll get coffee. Yes? Inspector Halloran, she's going through the material now. She'll call you... No, she'll be alright, I'll sleep over on the couch in case. But now, I told you, singing like a lark.

question: That's the face of the next one he'll kill. Look at the bottom of the screen. You see the icon with the arrow pointing left? Click on that... twice. That computer's wired into
answer: He's hacked into her Internet address. He's a hacker.

question: He can get into my computer any time he likes! This is exactly the kind of thing I didn't want to have happen. It's too big a file to copy to a disk.
answer: You got a tape backup, yeah, here lemme copy it on tape...

question: It's a game they like to play. Berkowitz -- "Son of Sam" -- hung around the crime scene, talking to the cops. This one's probably watching you, laughing at you.
answer: Let me get a little action started here.

question: One officer already got killed trying to protect me. Please, just take it all away. Leave me alone.
answer: Look at this...

question: It's gone. The file's not here. What did you do?
answer: I just started it copying to tape, but the tape never ran. It just did that...

question: I know 'Halloran.' What's the rest of it?
answer: MaryJane. We call her M.J.

question: MaryJane. You think that logic and police procedure, order and science and method will hold back the horrors of a world gone mad and the sickness of the night. I did once. But you know how he'll get caught? He'll have an accident, or some cop will get lucky. You can't catch him by being intelligent and working hard. Or the worst He's going home. He slept over because I was a little anxious...
answer: We're through for the night, aren't we? You go on. Get some sleep. I'll stay until we can get a man out here and maybe catch a cab home.

question: That would be much appreciated. Thanks.
answer: You ought to get some decent locks on these. A six-year-old could get in here. Much less a motivated man.

question: You and MaryJane aren't lovers.
answer: Not yet.

question: Are you always so bold?
answer: No. I'm shy and I'm selective. The problem for me is... you're in the witness category. Know what I mean?

question: Well. Another time, then. I'll be all right. He's not going to attack me; what I' m rally afraid of is all in my own head, Ruben.
answer: They'll have a guard here tomorrow. I know you have the idea, but it'll make me feel a lot better. Hey! The number for my cellular. Don't hesitate. Anytime. Night or day. I mean that.

question: Oh, God! Help me!
answer: Tell me what to do!

question: I'm falling! I'm going to fall! ...falling... FALLING!
answer: I'm right here. I won't let you fall.

question: Don't let go... I can't breathe... I'll die!
answer: Shhh. It's okay. Just breathe. I'll fix it... Put your hands over your ears.

question: The lock...
answer: I'll get a locksmith.

question: Put in the Kevin Costner.
answer: Why don't we save it for later? It's almost time for Letterman.

question: You know I don't like to watch talk shows by myself. Where're you? See, now you've annoyed her. You know she doesn't like you to touch me. Does she, widdle wee fing! Wuhve you so much! Did you feed her?
answer: Yes, I fed her. If she says she's hungry, she's lying to you. Again.

question: She doesn't lie! You sure you fed her?
answer: She lies all the time. Why would I say I fed her if I didn't?

question: That's what I don't know. Why would you lie? That's the problem... I can't understand why anyone would lie.
answer: Didn't I promise I'd come right back?

question: I know; the kid hit you first. He already told me.
answer: He's not treating her right...

question: She left you, Nikko. She's not your responsibility. She takes very good care of herself. If she wants to romance the kid, it ain't your business. Your business is to snap out of it.
answer: We were together six years, sir!

question: Don't give me six years! You never divorced Patty, did you? So what'd you expect from M.J.?
answer: She knows I'm Catholic! She never mentioned divorce! Not once!

question: Then you shoulda known she wasn't buying. She was just long-term leasing' you. Ah, Nickie. Except for that rare twenty-second twitch, there ain't nothin' about sex I don't hate. But of course, I'm Irish. Plus I got real problems. I'm worried I might have to put you in over M.J. There's something going on here, the Commissioner is targeting her now, I can't leave a woman in that position. But the thing is, how can I move you in, if you go on acting like a teenage asshole?
answer: I don't want the job. Don't do that to her. She's worked too damned hard for it.

question: I'm not seeing anybody. You're fired.
answer: I know. Do come and meet your guest.

question: That's no surprise. Then what do you need me for? You're saying it's the same man, but he's changed his style? That doesn't happen. These men are robotic; the murder is like a ritual. The method itself is part of the pleasure... I turned it off. It's like an open window he can climb right in... Have you got a warrant? Get the hell out o here! This is the only space I have left in the world! Why can't you leave me out of it? That little Winona Ryder manner... you're more convincing as Clint Eastwood.
answer: She's smoking again.

question: You betrayed me! Now every psychopath in the city knows I'm back in business... You lied to me! Why should I trust you? How could you...
answer: Yeah?... I can't talk now... What?... No. There's no sexual assault, it's a drive-by, a woman in a car, it's not him. Helen.

question: It's a woman shot in a car?
answer: Yes. I have to go...

question: She on the passenger side? What's that music. It's Abba. I can hear it. It's Abba.
answer: What's Abba?

question: Don't hang up!
answer: What?...

question: Listen to me. Is there a gas station nearby?
answer: Yes.

question: Is there a phone booth there?
answer: They all have one...

question: Go and look for a note.
answer: She wants me to check the phone booth for a note.

question: She was listening to Abba in her parked car when she was shot with a Bulldog .44. One of those goddamned car alarms. What's going... Look in the crowd. He liked to hang around and watch the cops at work...
answer: "Police Hold on a minute, Helen... The fuck you can! Helen! Are you okay? HELEN! Did this animal touch you? Turn on a light and call in the unit. NOW! Bullshit's gonna get your balls stomped on! What's your name? Then you get your ass outta here, I don't wanta see you again...

question: "Police Hold on a minute, Helen... The fuck you can! Helen! Are you okay? HELEN! Did this animal touch you? Turn on a light and call in the unit. NOW! Bullshit's gonna get your balls stomped on! What's your name? Then you get your ass outta here, I don't wanta see you again...
answer: I brought a present for the lady, there. I'm looking for her, to give her the present...

question: You break into her apartment to deliver a gift? Where is it?
answer: The door was open, swear to God, I'm just looking for her when you come charging up the stairs...

question: Where is it?
answer: I'm trying to tell you. It's on the lady's pillow... Daryll Lee Cullum, he wrote that book, he wanted the lady to have it. They won't let him send it to her, so I'm getting out, he asks me to deliver it in person, he says, put it on her pillow. It has all about how he tried to kill her.

question: He told you she was loaded, any- thing you could steal you could keep, Conrad? You bought yourself a return ticket to Quentin, breaking and entering.
answer: The door was already open...

question: We know... Send the book to evidence...
answer: She's supposed to have it.

question: She don't want it. Helen? Open the door. The guy's nothing. A burglar. Open the door. Please.
answer: Why don't you shoot off the lock? He was in my apartment!

question: I know, baby. I know. It's okay... you're safe with me! When I was a little kid, and I'd be in a state, my father would hold me on his lap, until all the fight would go out of me...
answer: You think you're my Daddy?

question: Helen...honey, you know I gotta go. You know how to use this?
answer: They taught me at the FBI. I was very good at it. It scared me... I liked it.

question: You take it, hang on to it, it'll make you feel safer. Stay put.
answer: What else?

question: Of course he wants to do a threesome! Only Bundy did three in one day. Is Bundy next? But Bundy should be last... the grand finale. What about Kemper and Ramirez? Gacy, Dahmer, Williams? Rivkind? Who else is on his list? In what order? '...great dark hall of fame... all our greatest killers...' His greatest heroes? He wants to be famous. When they're caught and people like me write about them, we give them a kind of immortality. They get thousands of letters. Ramirez kills eight women and gets a hundred marriage proposals a month. They're like film stars. Would you fax those pages to me? If we keep going and work till midnight...
answer: Sorry, Luv. I've got a date.

question: You've got a date right here, Andy. This has got to...
answer: It's almost six. And guess what? Hall likes me bathed and shaved.

question: Stop acting like a silly little fag!
answer: My life to live, darling, try to remember what it was like way, way back when you were young and sexy and alive.

question: You bastard!
answer: But alive!

question: It's not a real name Let's speed up the game plan... call all the living serials to ask if they've had contact with a Peter Kurten. We could use some help on the phones... You do that one, I don't want it... Not a damn bit... Hello, Daryll Lee.
answer: You read my book which as you know, hit the stands a couple of weeks ago. You read it yet.

question: What book?
answer: I sent it by private courier, he didn't give it to you? That son of a gun...!

question: I'll look for it, Daryll Lee.
answer: Bet you never figured I'd follow in your footsteps. It's real well- written. You should read it -- you're in it.

question: I will. I'll call you, Daryll, and talk to you about it after I've read it. Right now I have a question... Peter Kurten.
answer: Kurten! Is he bothering you? I told that son I'd send him what he wanted if he leave you alone.

question: Ah ha. What did he want?
answer: Something personal. Is he bothering you?

question: I don't know. I'd like to know where he is.
answer: Listen, you want my advice? Steer clear. He's writing me he's gonna finish 'my unfinished symphony.' He's gonna give me $550 for some of my cum, he says he's in a position to see that I will be immortal if he has some of my spunk. I'm offended. Right away I smell freak. Writin' about him and me and you bein' joined and he's gonna finish my symphony? I didn't care for his drift. I sent some liquid soap in a sandwich baggie with a message from Jesus to mend his ways. You hear I found Jesus? And what's funny is, now I don't mind bein' inside. If I was out, even Born Again, I'd probably get restless again. It's maybe better I stay here, what do you think?

question: I think whatever is best for you, Daryll. And maybe you're right, that's the place.
answer: You come and visit.

question: Where did you send the message to Peter Kurten?
answer: Damn! I gave that to Conrad, too! That guy! I told Conrad deliver to Kurten and keep the 500 bucks in return for getting my book to you.

question: How was Conrad supposed to find Kurten?
answer: Conrad has the phone number. Conrad, where is he?

question: In jail.
answer: That Klutz. They send him back here, I'll kick his ass good.

question: You speak English? You need an interpreter?
answer: I didn't want the Illigals, I wanted just the bastards dumping them in the harbor. What's keeping those bums at Immigration? Nightmare in here...

question: Outta your mind? Look at this...
answer: You got a suspect... How'd you get in on the deal? You have no authority to make a deal like that. That' s for the Saks. If he knew you did that! They're all asking me, 'what is she doing,' as it is. Nikko?

question: I don't believe it. They never kill themselves. How do you know it was him. You never met him. You never even saw a photograph... He hasn't done Bundy. He's done every one of the others, hasn't he? If there are three dead Chi Omega college girls tomorrow, how will you feel? Go there. See if there could be any way for him to escape. If there's a one percent possibil- ity, can you live with yourself when he kills again? Where are you?
answer: Hi. It's your worst student, Peter Foley -- how do you grade me now, Doctor?

question: Who was the man in the basement?
answer: You like that action? Didn't that cop on TV look solemn? The guy in the basement doesn't matter, anyway, just another lonely heart.

question: Where are you, Peter?
answer: You thought I was going to do Ted Bundy next, so you sent your partner... What was that? What am I hearing? The sound of an epiphany, a sudden blinding insight?

question: It's Daryll Lee Cullum, isn't it?
answer: Mm-hmm. I can't get to you. You have to come to me.

question: You know I can't do that.
answer: Oh, I think you will.

question: For God's sake Peter, leave her out of it. You don't want her, you want me.
answer: I need her; she's a cop. I have to kill a cop, and then...

question: You've been perfect. Don't spoil the symmetry -- you have to have a male cop.
answer: I don't care -- she's a cop. That's the important thing. Cop-ness, not sex-ness. It won't be perfect, but it'll be good. I'm tired. I want it to end tonight, don't you?

question: Yes. I do. I want it to end now. Let her go. I'll come -- just let her go. She's not important.
answer: You know where.

question: Where it began -- McCluskey Auditorium. It's all over, Fred. They got the guy. You go home to your own bed now. Call in. Use my phone. They'll tell you -- it's all over.
answer: Ma'am, please get out of your vehicle...

question: Merry, how... oh, Christ, of course, you had my phone tapped.
answer: Just get out of your vehicle...

question: He's got Sergeant Halloran in there. He'll kill her the minute he sees or hears your people...
answer: You've been very useful, Doctor, we appreciate all you've done, and now the professional will take over...

question: He wants me, he doesn't care about her. Let me...
answer: Go. Go. Go!

question: You cheated! You said you'd come die with me. Listen to them! We'll be on all three channels.
answer: Kill me, Peter, do it, now.

question: No. Not yet.
answer: Do it. If that's what all this carnage is about, then do it. Have enough guts to do it.

question: Don't talk to me about courage. I know death, what it's like to kill. You're not a killer -- you watched Daryll Lee kill that cop and you didn't make a peep, because you were paralyzed with fear. You chocked. I know something else about you. You want one? No? There was something in you that was fascinated, that wanted to see what it was like for a man to die. Everybody feels it. Like every person who slows to see a bad accident, or runs to see a fire. That's true. I see it in you... you're the same as me. Oh, no. We'll keep talking. Until they get here. Then...
answer: I have no life anymore. I ruined your life, make me pay for it.

question: Why did you do that? Didn't you have any idea how hard it was for me, to get that far? I worshipped you. You inspired me. I thought you could understand me the way you understood the others. I knew that about you -- the ones you admired were the great murderers; they fascinated you.
answer: That's not who I admire -- I admire people who are good at what they do, great artists, writers, thinkers...

question: I don't have the talent for any of those things. All I have a talent for is death. And I am one of a kind. What do you think of your student now? I have made you famous, I am your creation and your monument.
answer: If you let me, I can make you more famous than any of them.

question: Oh, please. I know what's coming, now. "Let me help you..."
answer: Do anything you want to me. I give myself to you. Only put the knife down. Isn't this what you always wanted? I know it's what we all want, to love and to loved. I could love you. You could work together in some safe place, learn to really understand you, help you, give you some peace of mind, some happiness...

question: Back in the driver's seat again, Doctor? That old dream -- study us to see what makes us sick. So you can find a cure -- they'd name it after you? Death is the only cure for people like me.
answer: Do it. For God's sake, now...
